title: Introduction to Computing - Short Notes
html:
Short Notes of CS101

ðŸš€ Welcome to CS101 â€“ Introduction to Computing

ðŸŽ¯ CS101 is your gateway to understanding the fundamental concepts of computing. It's about how computers work, from the physical parts you can touch to the instructions that make them perform amazing tasks. Sounds exciting? ðŸ¤” Donâ€™t worry, it's not that hard once you focus on logic and concepts.

This subject covers a wide range of topics, from basic computer components to how they connect and communicate globally. You donâ€™t need to memorize everything â€” just grasp the ideas, understand how things work, and practice a little. ðŸ’¡

This document will guide you through the essential concepts of CS101 in a simple and engaging way. Come on champ! Letâ€™s conquer Introduction to Computing together! ðŸš€

Week 1: Introduction & Search Fundamentals

Module 1: Introduction to Computer Science

Computer Science is a discipline that builds a scientific foundation for various computing topics, including:

  • Hardware: Physical parts of a computer system.
  • Software: Instructions and documentation that tell a computer what to do.
  • Programming: Designing and building executable computer programs.
  • Networks: Computers connected for sharing resources.
  • Graphics: Generating images with computers.
  • Robots: Programmable machines.
  • Database: Organized collection of data.
  • Security: Controls for confidentiality, integrity, and availability of computer system components.
  • Algorithmic Solutions: A set of instructions to perform a task.
  • Information Processing: Manipulation of digitized information by computers.

1.2 Computer Science Applications

Computer Science is applied in almost all domains, such as Telecom, Banks, Hospitals, Software Development, Service Industry, Pak Army, Freelancing, and many more.

1.3 Local Job Market (Pakistan)

Job opportunities in Computer Science are consistently high, prevalent both when filtered "By Function" and "By Industry".

1.4 International Job Market

Internationally, Computer Science jobs also rank at the top (e.g., Software Developer ranked #1 by Forbes).

Key highly ranked areas include Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning, Data Science, Virtual Reality, IoT, Back-End Developer, Front-End Developer, UI Designer, Full-Stack Engineer, IT Manager, Quality Assurance Expert.

1.5 Are you not a student of Computer Science?

This course covers fundamental Computer Science concepts essential for any field of study. It's designed to be easy and interactive.

Week 2: Breadth First Learning & Search Engines (Part 1)

Module 2: Breadth First Learning

This course introduces almost all Computer Science subjects, a strategy known as Breadth First Learning, in contrast to Depth First Learning.

It helps students understand the entire degree program's scope by covering an abstract view of major CS courses.

Introduction to Topics Covered in This Course:

  • 2.1 Search Engine Usage Techniques: Learn effective search techniques.
  • 2.2 History of Computing: Explore the evolution of modern computers.
  • 2.3 Data Storage: Understand how data is stored.
  • 2.4 Data Manipulation: Study how data is processed.
  • 2.5 Operating System: Learn about the OS.
  • 2.6 Networking and the Internet: Discover how computers communicate online.
  • 2.7 Algorithms: Grasp the fundamental concept of algorithms.
  • 2.8 Programming Languages: Study basic programming tools.
  • 2.9 Software Engineering: Cover the software development lifecycle.
  • 2.10 Data Abstraction: Learn how data abstraction simplifies design.
  • 2.11 Database Systems: Explore organized data storage and linking.
  • 2.12 Artificial Intelligence: Discover this specialized field.
  • 2.13 CS Impact on Society: Learn about the influence of Computer Science on society.
  • 2.14 Content Filtering, Spam, International laws: Cover content filtering, spam management, and related laws.
  • 2.15 Word Processing: Explore major functionalities of word processor software.
  • 2.16 Presentations Development: Learn to design presentations.
  • 2.17 Spreadsheet: Understand specialized software for data calculations.
  • 2.18 Database MS Access: Implement database concepts using Microsoft Access.
  • 2.19 Web Page Development: Learn to create web pages.

Module 3: Search Engines

Search Engines (e.g., Google, Yahoo, MSN) index web pages to retrieve relevant results based on your queries.

We will focus on Google due to its widespread use.

3.1 Query

A query is the set of words provided to a search engine for searching.

3.2 How Google Works

Google finds pages containing all terms in your query.

3.4 Use of Microphone

You can search by speaking using the microphone option.

3.5 Flip a Coin

Google can simulate a coin flip by typing "Flip a Coin".

3.6 Query Formulation

Always use precise terms for effective searching.

3.7 Capitalization

Google searches are case-insensitive.

Week 3: Search Tricks & Operators (Part 1)

Module 4: Searching Tricks

4.1 Weather Searching

To find weather information, add the location to "Weather" (e.g., "Weather Lahore").

4.2 Performing Calculations on Google

Google acts as a calculator; type mathematical expressions directly (e.g., "12*391").

4.3 Currency Conversion

Google provides real-time currency conversions (e.g., "100 euro to pkr").

Module 5: Search Operators (1)

5.1 Search on Social Media

Use the "@" symbol to search on specific social media platforms (e.g., "Fifa World cup @facebook").

5.2 Search for a Price

To search for items within a price range, add the currency before the amount (e.g., "Laptop pkr 50000").

Week 4: Search Operators (Part 2 & 3)

Module 5 (Cont.): Search Operators (2)

5.3 Hashtag Search

Use the "#" symbol to search for hashtags (e.g., "#WorldCup2014").

5.4 Exclude Words

Use the "-" (minus) symbol to exclude words from your search results (e.g., "Football -history" will show results for football but not those including the word 'history').

5.5 Search for exact match

Use double quotes (" ") around words to search for an exact phrase (e.g., "Virtual University of Pakistan"). This is one of the most useful search operators.

5.6 Search for either of two options

Use the "OR" operator between words to search for either one of them (e.g., "Computer OR Science").

5.7 Search within a range of numbers

Use two dots (..) between two numbers to search within a numeric range (e.g., "Virtual University of Pakistan 2005..2015").

Module 6: Search Operators (3)

6.1 Search within a Specific Site

Use the "site:" operator to search for content within a particular website (e.g., "admission site:www.vu.edu.pk").

6.2 Search Related Sites

Use the "related:" operator to find websites similar to a given URL (e.g., "related:vu.edu.pk").

6.3 Get info about a site

Use the "info:" operator to get information about a specific website (e.g., "info:vu.edu.pk"). This can provide cached versions, similar pages, and pages linking to the site.

6.4 Search a specific type of file

Use the "filetype:" operator to search for specific file types like PDFs or PPTs (e.g., "CS101 filetype:pdf").

6.5 Cache

The "cache:" operator shows Google's cached version of a webpage (e.g., "cache:www.vu.edu.pk"). Useful if a live page is down.

6.6 Define

Use the "define:" operator to find the definition of a word (e.g., "define:algorithm").

6.7 Asterisk

The "*" (asterisk) acts as a wildcard, standing for any word. Useful for finding phrases when you forget a word (e.g., "A stitch in time * nine").

6.8 Intext

The "intext:" operator finds pages where a specific word appears within the text of the page (e.g., "computer science intext:programming").

ðŸŽ¯ Short Notes Wrap-Up (Part 2)

Youâ€™ve made great progress! ðŸŽ‰ We've moved through the introductory concepts and delved deep into powerful search techniques. Mastering these search operators will make you a pro at finding information online!

Keep learning, keep growing. You are doing amazing! ðŸš€ Best of luck champ â€” success is waiting for you!
